title: Kenta Hasegawa
text:
is a former <a href="Japan">Japan</a>ese <a href="Association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He played for the <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japan national team</a>.
Club career.
Hasegawa was educated at and played for <a href="Shimizu%20Higashi%20High%20School">Shimizu Higashi High School</a>. He won the national high school championship with his teammates including <a href="Katsumi%20Oenoki">Katsumi Oenoki</a> and <a href="Takumi%20Horiike">Takumi Horiike</a>. He continued his study and football at <a href="University%20of%20Tsukuba">University of Tsukuba</a> where he won the Kanto University League title in 1987.
After graduating from the university in 1988, he joined <a href="Japan%20Soccer%20League">Japan Soccer League</a> side <a href="Yokohama%20F.%20Marinos">Nissan Motors</a> (current <a href="Yokohama%20F.%20Marinos">Yokohama F. Marinos</a>). He contributed to the club winning the <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> twice in <a href="1988%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1988</a> and <a href="1989%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">1989</a>. When Japan's first-ever professional league <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a> started, <a href="Shimizu%20S-Pulse">Shimizu S-Pulse</a> was founded in his local city. He joined the club in 1992 and re-united with his high school teammates Oenoki and Horiike. He helped the club to win the <a href="J.League%20Cup">J.League Cup</a> in 1996. He retired as a Shimizu player after the club won the second stage of the <a href="1999%20J.League%20Division%201">J1 League 1999 season</a>. He played 207 league matches and scored 45 league goals in 7 seasons at Shimizu.
International career.
Hasegawa was capped 27 times and scored 4 goals for the <a href="Japan%20national%20football%20team">Japanese national team</a> between 1989 and 1995. His first international appearance came on January 20, 1989 in a friendly against <a href="Iran%20national%20football%20team">Iran</a> in <a href="Teheran">Teheran</a>. He scored for the first time for his country on June 11, 1989 in a <a href="1990%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%29">1990 World Cup qualification</a> against <a href="Indonesia%20national%20football%20team">Indonesia</a> at <a href="Ajinomoto%20Field%20Nishigaoka">Nishigaoka Soccer Stadium</a> in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a>. He was a member of the Japan squad who participated in the <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28AFC%29">1994 World Cup qualification</a> for the <a href="1994%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1994 World Cup</a>. In the crucial last match, Hasegawa was substituted in the 59th minute by <a href="Masahiro%20Fukuda">Masahiro Fukuda</a> and watched from the bench a late Iraqi equaliser dashed Japan's hope to qualify for the finals in the US, the match that the Japanese fans now refer to as the <a href="1993%20Japan%20v%20Iraq%20football%20match">Agony of Doha</a>.
Coaching career.
After retiring from the game, Hasegawa started working as a pundit for national television <a href="NHK">NHK</a>. He was also installed as the general manager of two university clubs, <a href="Hamamatsu%20University">Hamamatsu University</a> and <a href="Fuji%20Tokoha%20University">Fuji Tokoha University</a> (2000–2001). He became the manager of Hamamatsu University and lead them to win the Tokai University League title and the Shizuoka Prefectural qualification for the <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a>. He acquired the S-class coaching license that was required to manage a J1 League club in 2004 and became the manager of his old club <a href="Shimizu%20S-Pulse">Shimizu S-Pulse</a> in 2005. The club struggled and narrowly escaped relegation in the 2005 season but they fought back strongly in the 2006 season and finished 4th in the league; a position equaled in 2007. In 2008 Hasegawa led S-Pulse to the final of the <a href="2008%20J.League%20Cup">J.League Cup</a> and a fifth-placed finish in the league, a placing which included them being the strongest performing team in the second half of the season. He was rewarded with an extended contract which will keep him at S-Pulse until 2010. He left Shimizu after he led the club to the final of 2010-11 <a href="Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> when his contract was expired.
Hawegawa was appointed as a manager at <a href="J2%20League">J2 League</a> club <a href="Gamba%20Osaka">Gamba Osaka</a> in 2013. The club won the champions in 2013 and was promoted to <a href="J1%20League">J1 League</a>. In 2014, the club won all three major title in Japan; <a href="2014%20J.League%20Division%201">J1 League</a>, <a href="2014%20J.League%20Cup">J.League Cup</a> and <a href="2014%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a>. He also was selected J.League Manager of the Year awards. In 2015, the club won the champions at <a href="2015%20Emperor%27s%20Cup">Emperor's Cup</a> and 2nd place at <a href="2015%20J1%20League">J1 League</a> and <a href="2015%20J.League%20Cup">J.League Cup</a>. He resigned end of 2017 season.
In 2018, Hasegawa signed with <a href="FC%20Tokyo">FC Tokyo</a>. In 2021, after a three year spell in which the club finished 6th, 2nd, 6th, and 9th in four respective seasons, Hasegawa resigned after an 8 - 0 loss to 2nd place <a href="Yokohama%20F.%20Marinos">Yokohama F. Marinos</a>. 
Shortly after the conclusion of the J1 league's 21/22 season, Hasegawa signed a contract with J1 league club <a href="Nagoya%20Grampus">Nagoya Grampus</a>.

Update; "November 6, 2021"
In popular culture.
In popular <a href="manga">manga</a> and <a href="anime">anime</a> series "<a href="Chibi%20Maruko-chan">Chibi Maruko-chan</a>", a boy called Kenta <a href="Japanese%20honorifics%23Kun">kun</a> occasionally makes an appearance. He loves football and is a classmate of title character Chibi Maruko. <a href="Momoko%20Sakura">Momoko Sakura</a>, the author of the manga, created this character after Hasegawa. Sakura and Hasegawa attended the same primary school during the same period.
